content:
The way Chinese Dim Sum meant to be served. Fast & efficient. I love that they have the same menu on the weekday and weekend. It gets really crowded on the weekends so come on a weekday if you can. You will not miss out on any items.

The porridge was particularly good on the day I visited. The service is simple and homely.

Enjoyed my meal there.

Large seating area with plenty of space.
Glutinous rice is a mushy, flavorful rice. The porridge was particularly good on the day I visited. The service is simple and homely.

I didn't get to order the Egg Tart as I would think it is overpriced for 3 small tarts.

Dim sum experience as close as how its supposed to be. Large seating area with plenty of space. Dim sum quality is great! Love the mini egg tarts especially. Expect to queue especially during weekend mornings where family gather for delicious Dim Sum breakfast.

Good service and good dim sum. including the porridge and carrot cake
The push cart is on during weekend for better efficiency.
Better enjoy during weekday
Their signature dishes are mostly good  with ngoh hiang fritter, braised duck and fried hor fun

Service is good, but is good to reserve the seat before heading down for dinner.
Location easy to find and been there for year so mostly people can locate the place
Parking just right behind of the library there is open car park..

Located on the second story above Giant supermarket, you have to look for the stairs in the center of the building. There is a long queue and it starts from the stairs. We waited for about 35 minutes in the morning for the ala carte dim sum. You can order Teochew dishes from 11am onwards. There is a high tea dim sum buffet from 3-5pm.

The restaurant is spacious, have more than 50 seats and can serve large crowds. Ordering of food is done from the dim sum pushcarts when the staff pushes them around, told us what they have and asked if we want any. You can check with them if they have any of the items you want to order on their pushcarts. Staff was friendly and service was good and fast.

It is a nice experience to get the food like in the authentic Hong Kong dim sum restaurants, but you can't explore all the dishes as you do not know the menu / the dishes available and their prices. From what we spent, the dim sum is about $5.80 per item on average. The steamed items are cheaper than the fried ones.

Swatow Restaurant served lovely Tea Dim Sum at Toa Payoh. Food are great with Pleasantly Courtesy Service staffs namely Madam Tee, Madam Chua (Da Mei)
Both always smiley and very efficient with their service.
In fact most of service officers were very polite.

I’ll share what I like about here, the service crew, an old aunty, brown bronze shoulder length hair, when we ask her why isn’t the steam bao troller coming, she offered to help us get the char siew and chee Chong fan, she’s also very attentive and responsive. As for the food quality, I’d say most of their ingredients are really fresh, especially in times like this. I’d highly recommend the char siew bao and siew mai, the fried food is above average.. I wouldn’t recommend the chee chong fan, because the char siew tasted frozen, but interestingly the char siew in the char siew bao is fresh. You can tell when the meat is not fresh because they will use a lot pepper in the meat, trying to cover the taste. Har Gao has a lot of pepper, skin is thick too. Porridge is rather blend, steam pork rib is fresh thou. The sesame mango prawn roll is pretty good too, thou the mango has not much taste. We spend about 60 ish for all the food in the photos provided. If you do intend to visit, I’d recommend you to make reservations.

One of the creamiest roe, at one of the best prices for cold crab I’ve ever had. For the quality to value ratio, this is easily a 5 star rating, if not because of some disappointments.

Although the other dishes were good - average, the other 2 highlights were a little disappointing. The steamed promfret (0.9kg) was perhaps a little too big so the flesh was a little bit boring. I would opt for a smaller fish for a sweeter & more tender experience. The teochew style crayfish just didn’t suit my palette, it ended tasting like eating onion fried eggs… it’s ok but I wouldn’t order it again.

Overall, still a highly recommended place for casual meals!

Review for : Take away for dinner. +  weekday dim sum buffet.

Dimsum buffet: Book and start the buffet at 3pm. As with everyone else, you'll be given an appetiser and pot of tea before the ala carte dishes is served in push carts. Going when it first starts ensures that you get a portion of all the dishes available as the service progresses. The dishes are served in good timing and don't rush to have multiple servings of each dish, unless u really want to, as there's new dishes constantly up until the 1hr20mins-ish mark where desserts start. Some dishes were a hit, (custard bun, red bean banana roll, char siew bao, siew mai, fish skin) some were mediocre (lotus glutinous rice, century egg porridge, egg tart). But otherwise, it's good value. Definitely worth it, had 20ish dishes between the 2 of us. We were super stuffed just an hr in.

Take away dinner: the lady taking our order was frank with regards to what dishes were good to order as take away. Generally, the food was decent, the duck was flavorful and tender. Radish fried kway teow was flavourful, altho the small portion was half size that of the small portion of the eefu. The sesame pork was a little disappointing, as it was just roasted sesame salad sauce with pork, not unique or memorable, can pass. * Note: takeaway orders have 20% off for almost all dishes. Offer not valid for delivery or dine in. Validity till unknown.

Spent our Sunday morning having #Dimsum
🥟
It has been a long time since we last came. Service is prompt and dimsum taste pretty ok. There is a lot of variety and service is prompt in serving. A bit pricey but overall it is decent.

Impeccable service - staff were very friendly and polite. They were also extremely attentive and kept refilling the tea.

Cold crab was good, other food was pretty mediocre. Chicken was extremely salty.

5 stars for the service, 3.5 stars for the food.

We will bring our family here for dim sums, thus this will be a frequent visit for us. Glutinous rice is a mushy, flavorful rice. The crystal veg bun is fluffy and somewhat spicy. Siew Mai is a lovely. The lui Sai bun is fantastic. I enjoy their egg tarts as well, but I was unable to order egg tarts and mini Xiao long bao this time.

Got chased out of the place because we spent more than the 90 mins that was given to us.

I understand the logic when there's a long queue waiting for tables but what we are seeing is there's plenty of tables with no queue at all.

We were still taking our time to eat and intend to continue ordering more, but since their business is "so good" to the extent they need to chase customers out, i guess i have to find other options next time

Dim Sum buffet. They serve pretty fast, keeping coming to the table with offer of different dishes; we don't even need to call for waitress. We end up with 13 dishes + 2 dessert. (We rejected a few other dishes becuz too full). The prawns are fresh,  baos are nice. Only setback is the pork ribs which is abit too salty. The fried red bean + banana pancake was abit too sweet. Worth going back again

Dim sum buffet for $28.80++ from 3pm to 5pm

Tea included with around 30 dishes + dessert to choose from..

No need to order.. Aunty push dishes to you.. Wan how many just tell aunty..

At this price.. With nice food.. Good service..

Can come again!!

Food was okay, but on the pricy side. The service was prompt and the vibes was right for a Chinese restaurant. Was there for a weekday lunch, and it was relatively busy. I’d suggest the weekend dim sum buffet instead for under $40. It’s more value for the money you’re paying.

I’m reviewing the dim sum buffet that is available on weekdays 3pm-5pm. Their style is they will serve dish by dish via push carts instead of ordering yourself. And when all dishes are served, there will be a ‘last order’.

The problem came when they served the Xiao Long Bao, I told the server to give our table 4 trays, but to my surprise there are only 2 pieces per tray. But all other dim sums have 3 pieces?? Hence it’s not enough for my table so I ask another staff to get us more xlb, but she said there will be last order soon and we can order as many as we want. Ok. So during the last order, I asked for 8 trays of xlb and nothing else, 10mins later the staff came out and apologise that there are no more xlb. Erm….. I’m paying for a ‘buffet’, I don’t understanding what they mean no more xlb, if no more then the chefs can make more right?
Really made me lose face since I’m the organiser, my table some eat 1 piece some eat 2 pieces only, despite being a ‘buffet’.

Most of the food was great though. Maintained the same standard as during my last visit before covid.

This is the best Push Cart DIM SUM buffet that I ever had in Singapore. The restaurant looks exactly like Yam Cha place. We have 1.5hrs to gets the foods and even the waitress will come to you for the last orders, so that you can order your favourite dishes as a happy ending! I like their Xiao Long Bao,Golden Custard Pau, Har Kao,Siew Mai,Paper Wrapped with Chicken,chicken claws with spices,fried spring roll and crispy shrimps dumpling. I love their dessert especially the Red Bean Paste and banan pastry and Sweet Almond longan.The price is $67.80 for 2 pax (included GST and service charges) which I think it is quite reasonable and value for money.I definitely will visit Swatow Seafoods again when craving for Dim Sum even though it is far from my living place.

Good dim sum place in the mature Toa Payoh housing estate. Location is so accessible.  There is also a lift, albeit a very basic and simple model for those who need assistance.  Just give a call to the number for assistance.
Glad that the management is able to pull through the Covid period.  Saw many families, old & young.

Some food nice some food not so nice.
The service okok but we were placed at a corner of the restaurant and the push cart didnt go to our side so we gotta wait very long to order our food. And you can only order your food via the push cart. I also dont know why the push cart didnt go around the restaurant systematically.

Pretty good selection at the dim sum buffet, very friendly and helpful staff as well. Carts came around quite frequently with new dishes still warm in their steamers. Worth the money for a good gathering.

The cold crab is ok but the rest is not nice. I had lowered my standard but still fail beyond commercial standard.The teochew fried kway teow, oyster omelet n especially the  signature pomfret is totally disappointed. Poor taste. I think my wife, a housewife can cook very much better. Dun understand such a popular teochew restaurant provide such low standard. Too surprise to me liao. How to go back?
Personal favorite cold crab (not cheap), braised duck and cai Poh Kueh teow and orrh nee. The rest of the dishes are okie.

Spent about $195 for 5 pax for afternoon teochew dim sum. The braised duck was a bit chewy but tasty. The signature steamed chicken is also not as tender as I expected. The yam paste with pumpkin dessert was not too sweet or oily, just nice for elderly people with delicate pallette. Honestly I wouldn't say the dim sum was that great, I still prefer Cantonese styled dim sum at places like Tim Ho Wan etc. Overall, quite reasonable for the price. Reservations at least 3 weeks in advance recommended but for walk in customers, arriving after 1pm is better (less crowded) especially on weekends.

We ordered the set menu for 6 comprising, crispy fish skin topping on salad with sliced baby abalone, shark fin in egg broth, steamed promfret, prawn with tofu broth, vegetables with mushrooms, and yam paste dessert. We swapped the chicken dish for sliced goose meat snd ordered an additional dish of teochew fried kuay teow with diced spring onions snd crispy fried pork lard.

We went at around 1+pm and our last order is at 145pm for the dim sums as we need to vacate out by 2.30pm so that they can prepare for the 3pm buffet dim sum.

Food is good, except for the egg tart that is not those that don't have many crispy layers,  chicken feet is nice but can be softer,  I feel that they did not cook long enough, as for the rest of the dishes are good,  spring roll are crispy,  deep fried wanton is nice,  carrot cake with xo sauce,  century egg porridge,  fried prawn with mango also very nice.  I don't really like their chee cheong fan as the cha siew got a little bit of the pork smell which I'm scare of.  The cha siew bao is nice,  the lotus rice is nice too.  If you love to eat dim sum at a reasonable price,  you can come here or other outlets to try it out.  Service is fast and food serving is fast too.
Authentic teochew restaurant. Dim sum are served in push cart trolley. We love their Liu Sha Bao, Zhi ma bao, Zhu jiao chu, the rest of the items are also okay. The waitresses are very friendly too.

Best!! Love the dimsum buffet! They literally flood your table with food!! The siew mai is one of the best I have tried. With flounder powder. True teochew style. Dimsum are served hot, fresh prawns filling! Aunties are super friendly. Love the place. Will refer it to all my friends!!!!!

If you are craving push cart dimsum this is one of the few places that serves it, they start 8am.

Food quality is average The skin of har gow is so so n thick .  Seafood Bamboo roll was nice .  But found the char siew Chee Cheong fun to have porky smell .
Food is terrible. waiting 1.5hr only server 2 out of 8 dishes my kids are hungry. this restaurant put coriander in the sharkfin soup ruin the taste. pepper shaker also doesn’t work. upsetting.
having a set dinner for two costs $48++. It is worth it. I love all dishes. It's nice and more than enough for two people. It is highly recommended.

Usually enjoy the century egg porridge, red bean banana and crystal dumplings here (not at our recent visit however). Find the other standard items - siew mai, har kao, char siew bao, liu sha bao, carrot cake - quite average. Not a fan of the egg tart (neither buttery nor flaky) or chee cheong fun (too thick).

We visited a few times in the last 2 years when they stopped push cart service. Now that they have resumed that, satisfaction has dropped somewhat. The fried items were dripping in oil. Given earlier experiences, will give it another shot before revising ratings downwards.

Service is more of a miss recently, and I feel the food standards have dropped tremendously of late.

The most disappointing thing is having 3 wait staff insist that it's "normal" for fried food to come drenched in oil. The paper liner is glazed full of oil.

Similar to our recent previous visit, I've also had to repeatedly chase the servers for status for the 1 last dish. It's really odd how they leave one last dish hanging like that, we just sat around having finished everything we've ordered but waiting for that one *final* dish.

Always visited in the morning ala carte dimsum period, but I guess not anymore.

Confirmed and chopped! Authentic push cart dim sum! Besides Red Star, this is the only other place with old style push cart service that I know of. And I have been looking for this on both sides of the border for some time now.

The dim sum still taste good after all these years. Not mind blowingly good but comfortably adhering to the taste you are used to and familiar with. The selection is somewhat limited and this is understandable due to manpower constraints. But they do have all the popular items like Siew Mai, Har Gao, Braised Chicken Feet, Steamed Pork Ribs, Char Siew Buns, Beancurd Skin Wraps, Chee Cheong Fun and Century Egg / Sliced Pork Porridge. Notably missing were Radish Cake and Lotus Leaf Wrapped Glutinous Rice. The one complain I have would be their rule for 90 mins service limit for each table, although I don’t really see them enforcing it.

Opens from 8am daily so yes, this is the one place in Singapore where you can enjoy a yum cha culture closest to that of Hong Kong. Call it nostalgia but the push cart system is a huge winner for me.

Enjoyed eating at this very traditional Teochew restaurant. The duck with tofu was great. Enjoyed the steam pomfret fish. Very fresh. The crawfish is good, pretty unique. The onions in it very nice. The egg with oyster nice. Their gravy has the oyster taste in it. Yam dessert was ok. Chicken was ok. The good thing is it’s super spacious. You could use some private room for karaoke as well. They serve dim sum too
Nice, authentic and Affordable price for Teochew cuisine with dim sum

Expect half the menu to be out of stock.

The waitress claimed it is because today “business was too good”. Excuse me, we have been sitting here since 7pm and your restaurant has not been full at any point of time.

At 8.30pm, they are left with 3 dessert options out of a list of more than 12. That’s 25%

My third trip to this restaurant, tried ordering the al carte menu. We ordered their famous Swatow Chicken which is really good, the flesh is tender and skin is smooth and melt in your mouth. The steam minced pork with salted fish is another dish not to be missed. Well flavored with slight hint of salted fish taste. The most surprising dish is the Teochew Kai Lan Fried Kuay Teow with Preserved Radish. Loved the char flavor and rice noodle is not overly oily. The preserved radish just add another dimension to the dish. Loved it and looking to come back and have it second time.

Sawtow seafood, been here twice with my parents to have Tim Sum. It is great that they have lift for elderly so don't have to walk up the stairs. Spacious dinning area, Tim Sum spread is fine with plenty of selection, however I prefer that they have a menu for customer to choice and they bring to our table instead having to wait for the server to push the cart and pick whatever you like. It also took me more than 10 minutes to settle my bills. Wish they have better work processes to make it more efficient for customer as well their employees. Very old school Chinese restaurant.

Just a #simple breakfast at 8am with the Bros... Red bean Jing Jing is damm dope... Well... #drifterdrift have #doneitagain #whoopwhoopwhoop

For @drifterdrift and @igymtoeatmore for more information

You will find traditional #DimSum here at #SwaTowSeafoodRestaurant (aka #汕头海鲜). Taste is decent and nostalgic. Been here for many years, however due to covid, last visit was about 2 years+ ago.
.
#StanzFoodHunts @swatowrestaurant #ChineseCuisine  #ChineseBreakfast #ToaPayoh

Read the good reviews and always enjoy the food and no issue with the service until today. I was there with family at 2.00pm but was shouted by a staff who claimed that last order is at 2pm., she addressed us as HALO , HALO when we were about to walk into the restaurant, saying that last order closed, but the lady at the reception was nicer, approached us and told us to come at 3pm for the buffet.  The staff need to be trained on how to approached the customer in a nicer way than to behave like she is in the market place,  Please educate your staff.

Made a reservation for a small family event. Private room provided was spacious for the number of tables booked. Came with karaoke. Very nice and cosy space for get-together and catching up. Service was good in general. Food was superb and did not disappoint. Very tasty and adequately portioned. Pricing was also very fair. Definitely left the restaurant with good memories and great vibes. Parking is open air, plenty and cheap.

This Swatow restaurant is located at 181 Toa Payoh #02-602,  Lorong 4, Singapore 310181.

This restaurant is quite spacious in all but not cooling enough.

We went for weekend buffet.  The restaurant was almost fully occupied; partly as being a Saturday, secondly there will be no dine-in from Sunday onwards.

The food were served very quickly by  push-carts crews.  There were quite a variety of food to opt for.  We did not take up some of the food offered in order not to waste.

The chicken feets if cooked in a little spicy way will be best.
The food and desserts were fine so far.

I came for breakfast and ordered the following dim sum:
1. Vinegar pork
2. Century egg porridge
3. Steamed pork ribs
4. Steamed chicken claw

Very good service. Overall the dishes are not bad, but the price is a little on the high side.
Lucky our queue wasn't too long. Had a great brunch and variety of dim sum to choose.

This is one of my tasty, authentic and value for money restaurant! My buddies and I couldn’t believe the reasonable pricing and the nostalgic taste we been missing all these years. The must try: Orh Lua, pig trotted jelly, fried caipoh Kuay Teow and caipoh egg. OMG. We going again next week! 👍🏻

Tried the Dim Sum and overall good experience. The pan fried Carrot Cake has good sear on it for favour and taste. The Salted Egg Lava Bun was so-so, didn't have that good oozing of the salted egg lava.

Do not go for the dim sum buffet. Web stated 3-5pm, 430pm the staff will chased all the customer away. A lot of item is not in the buffet. All staff very rude, attitude in services. Worst restaurant I ever been.
Old school dim sum house with waitresses pushing dim sum carts around. Taste is avg.

This Chinese food stall tucked in the extreme corner of the food court serves really good food! I had the salted egg pork rice for $6 and it was delicious! The salted egg gravy was thick and flavourful, and the pork nuggets were scrunchy and chewy.
Delicious food at affordable prices! Must try the curry fish head/tail. Nice wok hey for their hor fun. Petai is a must try if you are into it!
Had great pork ribs and curry pork rice. Bulls eye fried egg on the rice had just the right balance of runny yolk and crisp edges on the whites.
Booked 6 table on Saturday, the service was good and fast. Food was also very nice and tasty with reasonable price.

The way Chinese Dim Sum meant to be served. Fast & efficient. I love that they have the same menu on the weekday and weekend. It gets really crowded on the weekends so come on a weekday if you can. You will not miss out on any items.

The porridge was particularly good on the day I visited. The service is simple and homely.

Enjoyed my meal there.

Large seating area with plenty of space.
Glutinous rice is a mushy, flavorful rice. The porridge was particularly good on the day I visited. The service is simple and homely.

I didn't get to order the Egg Tart as I would think it is overpriced for 3 small tarts.

Dim sum experience as close as how its supposed to be. Large seating area with plenty of space. Dim sum quality is great! Love the mini egg tarts especially. Expect to queue especially during weekend mornings where family gather for delicious Dim Sum breakfast.

Good service and good dim sum. including the porridge and carrot cake
The push cart is on during weekend for better efficiency.
Better enjoy during weekday
Their signature dishes are mostly good  with ngoh hiang fritter, braised duck and fried hor fun

Service is good, but is good to reserve the seat before heading down for dinner.
Location easy to find and been there for year so mostly people can locate the place
Parking just right behind of the library there is open car park..

Located on the second story above Giant supermarket, you have to look for the stairs in the center of the building. There is a long queue and it starts from the stairs. We waited for about 35 minutes in the morning for the ala carte dim sum. You can order Teochew dishes from 11am onwards. There is a high tea dim sum buffet from 3-5pm.

The restaurant is spacious, have more than 50 seats and can serve large crowds. Ordering of food is done from the dim sum pushcarts when the staff pushes them around, told us what they have and asked if we want any. You can check with them if they have any of the items you want to order on their pushcarts. Staff was friendly and service was good and fast.

It is a nice experience to get the food like in the authentic Hong Kong dim sum restaurants, but you can't explore all the dishes as you do not know the menu / the dishes available and their prices. From what we spent, the dim sum is about $5.80 per item on average. The steamed items are cheaper than the fried ones.

Swatow Restaurant served lovely Tea Dim Sum at Toa Payoh. Food are great with Pleasantly Courtesy Service staffs namely Madam Tee, Madam Chua (Da Mei)
Both always smiley and very efficient with their service.
In fact most of service officers were very polite.

I’ll share what I like about here, the service crew, an old aunty, brown bronze shoulder length hair, when we ask her why isn’t the steam bao troller coming, she offered to help us get the char siew and chee Chong fan, she’s also very attentive and responsive. As for the food quality, I’d say most of their ingredients are really fresh, especially in times like this. I’d highly recommend the char siew bao and siew mai, the fried food is above average.. I wouldn’t recommend the chee chong fan, because the char siew tasted frozen, but interestingly the char siew in the char siew bao is fresh. You can tell when the meat is not fresh because they will use a lot pepper in the meat, trying to cover the taste. Har Gao has a lot of pepper, skin is thick too. Porridge is rather blend, steam pork rib is fresh thou. The sesame mango prawn roll is pretty good too, thou the mango has not much taste. We spend about 60 ish for all the food in the photos provided. If you do intend to visit, I’d recommend you to make reservations.

One of the creamiest roe, at one of the best prices for cold crab I’ve ever had. For the quality to value ratio, this is easily a 5 star rating, if not because of some disappointments.

Although the other dishes were good - average, the other 2 highlights were a little disappointing. The steamed promfret (0.9kg) was perhaps a little too big so the flesh was a little bit boring. I would opt for a smaller fish for a sweeter & more tender experience. The teochew style crayfish just didn’t suit my palette, it ended tasting like eating onion fried eggs… it’s ok but I wouldn’t order it again.

Overall, still a highly recommended place for casual meals!

Review for : Take away for dinner. +  weekday dim sum buffet.

Dimsum buffet: Book and start the buffet at 3pm. As with everyone else, you'll be given an appetiser and pot of tea before the ala carte dishes is served in push carts. Going when it first starts ensures that you get a portion of all the dishes available as the service progresses. The dishes are served in good timing and don't rush to have multiple servings of each dish, unless u really want to, as there's new dishes constantly up until the 1hr20mins-ish mark where desserts start. Some dishes were a hit, (custard bun, red bean banana roll, char siew bao, siew mai, fish skin) some were mediocre (lotus glutinous rice, century egg porridge, egg tart). But otherwise, it's good value. Definitely worth it, had 20ish dishes between the 2 of us. We were super stuffed just an hr in.

Take away dinner: the lady taking our order was frank with regards to what dishes were good to order as take away. Generally, the food was decent, the duck was flavorful and tender. Radish fried kway teow was flavourful, altho the small portion was half size that of the small portion of the eefu. The sesame pork was a little disappointing, as it was just roasted sesame salad sauce with pork, not unique or memorable, can pass. * Note: takeaway orders have 20% off for almost all dishes. Offer not valid for delivery or dine in. Validity till unknown.

Spent our Sunday morning having #Dimsum
🥟
It has been a long time since we last came. Service is prompt and dimsum taste pretty ok. There is a lot of variety and service is prompt in serving. A bit pricey but overall it is decent.

Impeccable service - staff were very friendly and polite. They were also extremely attentive and kept refilling the tea.

Cold crab was good, other food was pretty mediocre. Chicken was extremely salty.

5 stars for the service, 3.5 stars for the food.

We will bring our family here for dim sums, thus this will be a frequent visit for us. Glutinous rice is a mushy, flavorful rice. The crystal veg bun is fluffy and somewhat spicy. Siew Mai is a lovely. The lui Sai bun is fantastic. I enjoy their egg tarts as well, but I was unable to order egg tarts and mini Xiao long bao this time.

Got chased out of the place because we spent more than the 90 mins that was given to us.

I understand the logic when there's a long queue waiting for tables but what we are seeing is there's plenty of tables with no queue at all.

We were still taking our time to eat and intend to continue ordering more, but since their business is "so good" to the extent they need to chase customers out, i guess i have to find other options next time

Dim Sum buffet. They serve pretty fast, keeping coming to the table with offer of different dishes; we don't even need to call for waitress. We end up with 13 dishes + 2 dessert. (We rejected a few other dishes becuz too full). The prawns are fresh,  baos are nice. Only setback is the pork ribs which is abit too salty. The fried red bean + banana pancake was abit too sweet. Worth going back again

Dim sum buffet for $28.80++ from 3pm to 5pm

Tea included with around 30 dishes + dessert to choose from..

No need to order.. Aunty push dishes to you.. Wan how many just tell aunty..

At this price.. With nice food.. Good service..

Can come again!!

Food was okay, but on the pricy side. The service was prompt and the vibes was right for a Chinese restaurant. Was there for a weekday lunch, and it was relatively busy. I’d suggest the weekend dim sum buffet instead for under $40. It’s more value for the money you’re paying.

I’m reviewing the dim sum buffet that is available on weekdays 3pm-5pm. Their style is they will serve dish by dish via push carts instead of ordering yourself. And when all dishes are served, there will be a ‘last order’.

The problem came when they served the Xiao Long Bao, I told the server to give our table 4 trays, but to my surprise there are only 2 pieces per tray. But all other dim sums have 3 pieces?? Hence it’s not enough for my table so I ask another staff to get us more xlb, but she said there will be last order soon and we can order as many as we want. Ok. So during the last order, I asked for 8 trays of xlb and nothing else, 10mins later the staff came out and apologise that there are no more xlb. Erm….. I’m paying for a ‘buffet’, I don’t understanding what they mean no more xlb, if no more then the chefs can make more right?
Really made me lose face since I’m the organiser, my table some eat 1 piece some eat 2 pieces only, despite being a ‘buffet’.

Most of the food was great though. Maintained the same standard as during my last visit before covid.

This is the best Push Cart DIM SUM buffet that I ever had in Singapore. The restaurant looks exactly like Yam Cha place. We have 1.5hrs to gets the foods and even the waitress will come to you for the last orders, so that you can order your favourite dishes as a happy ending! I like their Xiao Long Bao,Golden Custard Pau, Har Kao,Siew Mai,Paper Wrapped with Chicken,chicken claws with spices,fried spring roll and crispy shrimps dumpling. I love their dessert especially the Red Bean Paste and banan pastry and Sweet Almond longan.The price is $67.80 for 2 pax (included GST and service charges) which I think it is quite reasonable and value for money.I definitely will visit Swatow Seafoods again when craving for Dim Sum even though it is far from my living place.

Good dim sum place in the mature Toa Payoh housing estate. Location is so accessible.  There is also a lift, albeit a very basic and simple model for those who need assistance.  Just give a call to the number for assistance.
Glad that the management is able to pull through the Covid period.  Saw many families, old & young.

Some food nice some food not so nice.
The service okok but we were placed at a corner of the restaurant and the push cart didnt go to our side so we gotta wait very long to order our food. And you can only order your food via the push cart. I also dont know why the push cart didnt go around the restaurant systematically.

Pretty good selection at the dim sum buffet, very friendly and helpful staff as well. Carts came around quite frequently with new dishes still warm in their steamers. Worth the money for a good gathering.

The cold crab is ok but the rest is not nice. I had lowered my standard but still fail beyond commercial standard.The teochew fried kway teow, oyster omelet n especially the  signature pomfret is totally disappointed. Poor taste. I think my wife, a housewife can cook very much better. Dun understand such a popular teochew restaurant provide such low standard. Too surprise to me liao. How to go back?
Personal favorite cold crab (not cheap), braised duck and cai Poh Kueh teow and orrh nee. The rest of the dishes are okie.

Spent about $195 for 5 pax for afternoon teochew dim sum. The braised duck was a bit chewy but tasty. The signature steamed chicken is also not as tender as I expected. The yam paste with pumpkin dessert was not too sweet or oily, just nice for elderly people with delicate pallette. Honestly I wouldn't say the dim sum was that great, I still prefer Cantonese styled dim sum at places like Tim Ho Wan etc. Overall, quite reasonable for the price. Reservations at least 3 weeks in advance recommended but for walk in customers, arriving after 1pm is better (less crowded) especially on weekends.

We ordered the set menu for 6 comprising, crispy fish skin topping on salad with sliced baby abalone, shark fin in egg broth, steamed promfret, prawn with tofu broth, vegetables with mushrooms, and yam paste dessert. We swapped the chicken dish for sliced goose meat snd ordered an additional dish of teochew fried kuay teow with diced spring onions snd crispy fried pork lard.

We went at around 1+pm and our last order is at 145pm for the dim sums as we need to vacate out by 2.30pm so that they can prepare for the 3pm buffet dim sum.

Food is good, except for the egg tart that is not those that don't have many crispy layers,  chicken feet is nice but can be softer,  I feel that they did not cook long enough, as for the rest of the dishes are good,  spring roll are crispy,  deep fried wanton is nice,  carrot cake with xo sauce,  century egg porridge,  fried prawn with mango also very nice.  I don't really like their chee cheong fan as the cha siew got a little bit of the pork smell which I'm scare of.  The cha siew bao is nice,  the lotus rice is nice too.  If you love to eat dim sum at a reasonable price,  you can come here or other outlets to try it out.  Service is fast and food serving is fast too.
Authentic teochew restaurant. Dim sum are served in push cart trolley. We love their Liu Sha Bao, Zhi ma bao, Zhu jiao chu, the rest of the items are also okay. The waitresses are very friendly too.

Best!! Love the dimsum buffet! They literally flood your table with food!! The siew mai is one of the best I have tried. With flounder powder. True teochew style. Dimsum are served hot, fresh prawns filling! Aunties are super friendly. Love the place. Will refer it to all my friends!!!!!

If you are craving push cart dimsum this is one of the few places that serves it, they start 8am.

Food quality is average The skin of har gow is so so n thick .  Seafood Bamboo roll was nice .  But found the char siew Chee Cheong fun to have porky smell .
Food is terrible. waiting 1.5hr only server 2 out of 8 dishes my kids are hungry. this restaurant put coriander in the sharkfin soup ruin the taste. pepper shaker also doesn’t work. upsetting.
having a set dinner for two costs $48++. It is worth it. I love all dishes. It's nice and more than enough for two people. It is highly recommended.

Usually enjoy the century egg porridge, red bean banana and crystal dumplings here (not at our recent visit however). Find the other standard items - siew mai, har kao, char siew bao, liu sha bao, carrot cake - quite average. Not a fan of the egg tart (neither buttery nor flaky) or chee cheong fun (too thick).

We visited a few times in the last 2 years when they stopped push cart service. Now that they have resumed that, satisfaction has dropped somewhat. The fried items were dripping in oil. Given earlier experiences, will give it another shot before revising ratings downwards.

Service is more of a miss recently, and I feel the food standards have dropped tremendously of late.

The most disappointing thing is having 3 wait staff insist that it's "normal" for fried food to come drenched in oil. The paper liner is glazed full of oil.

Similar to our recent previous visit, I've also had to repeatedly chase the servers for status for the 1 last dish. It's really odd how they leave one last dish hanging like that, we just sat around having finished everything we've ordered but waiting for that one *final* dish.

Always visited in the morning ala carte dimsum period, but I guess not anymore.

Confirmed and chopped! Authentic push cart dim sum! Besides Red Star, this is the only other place with old style push cart service that I know of. And I have been looking for this on both sides of the border for some time now.

The dim sum still taste good after all these years. Not mind blowingly good but comfortably adhering to the taste you are used to and familiar with. The selection is somewhat limited and this is understandable due to manpower constraints. But they do have all the popular items like Siew Mai, Har Gao, Braised Chicken Feet, Steamed Pork Ribs, Char Siew Buns, Beancurd Skin Wraps, Chee Cheong Fun and Century Egg / Sliced Pork Porridge. Notably missing were Radish Cake and Lotus Leaf Wrapped Glutinous Rice. The one complain I have would be their rule for 90 mins service limit for each table, although I don’t really see them enforcing it.

Opens from 8am daily so yes, this is the one place in Singapore where you can enjoy a yum cha culture closest to that of Hong Kong. Call it nostalgia but the push cart system is a huge winner for me.

Enjoyed eating at this very traditional Teochew restaurant. The duck with tofu was great. Enjoyed the steam pomfret fish. Very fresh. The crawfish is good, pretty unique. The onions in it very nice. The egg with oyster nice. Their gravy has the oyster taste in it. Yam dessert was ok. Chicken was ok. The good thing is it’s super spacious. You could use some private room for karaoke as well. They serve dim sum too
Nice, authentic and Affordable price for Teochew cuisine with dim sum

Expect half the menu to be out of stock.

The waitress claimed it is because today “business was too good”. Excuse me, we have been sitting here since 7pm and your restaurant has not been full at any point of time.

At 8.30pm, they are left with 3 dessert options out of a list of more than 12. That’s 25%

My third trip to this restaurant, tried ordering the al carte menu. We ordered their famous Swatow Chicken which is really good, the flesh is tender and skin is smooth and melt in your mouth. The steam minced pork with salted fish is another dish not to be missed. Well flavored with slight hint of salted fish taste. The most surprising dish is the Teochew Kai Lan Fried Kuay Teow with Preserved Radish. Loved the char flavor and rice noodle is not overly oily. The preserved radish just add another dimension to the dish. Loved it and looking to come back and have it second time.

Sawtow seafood, been here twice with my parents to have Tim Sum. It is great that they have lift for elderly so don't have to walk up the stairs. Spacious dinning area, Tim Sum spread is fine with plenty of selection, however I prefer that they have a menu for customer to choice and they bring to our table instead having to wait for the server to push the cart and pick whatever you like. It also took me more than 10 minutes to settle my bills. Wish they have better work processes to make it more efficient for customer as well their employees. Very old school Chinese restaurant.

Just a #simple breakfast at 8am with the Bros... Red bean Jing Jing is damm dope... Well... #drifterdrift have #doneitagain #whoopwhoopwhoop

For @drifterdrift and @igymtoeatmore for more information

You will find traditional #DimSum here at #SwaTowSeafoodRestaurant (aka #汕头海鲜). Taste is decent and nostalgic. Been here for many years, however due to covid, last visit was about 2 years+ ago.
.
#StanzFoodHunts @swatowrestaurant #ChineseCuisine  #ChineseBreakfast #ToaPayoh

Read the good reviews and always enjoy the food and no issue with the service until today. I was there with family at 2.00pm but was shouted by a staff who claimed that last order is at 2pm., she addressed us as HALO , HALO when we were about to walk into the restaurant, saying that last order closed, but the lady at the reception was nicer, approached us and told us to come at 3pm for the buffet.  The staff need to be trained on how to approached the customer in a nicer way than to behave like she is in the market place,  Please educate your staff.

Made a reservation for a small family event. Private room provided was spacious for the number of tables booked. Came with karaoke. Very nice and cosy space for get-together and catching up. Service was good in general. Food was superb and did not disappoint. Very tasty and adequately portioned. Pricing was also very fair. Definitely left the restaurant with good memories and great vibes. Parking is open air, plenty and cheap.

This Swatow restaurant is located at 181 Toa Payoh #02-602,  Lorong 4, Singapore 310181.

This restaurant is quite spacious in all but not cooling enough.

We went for weekend buffet.  The restaurant was almost fully occupied; partly as being a Saturday, secondly there will be no dine-in from Sunday onwards.

The food were served very quickly by  push-carts crews.  There were quite a variety of food to opt for.  We did not take up some of the food offered in order not to waste.

The chicken feets if cooked in a little spicy way will be best.
The food and desserts were fine so far.

I came for breakfast and ordered the following dim sum:
1. Vinegar pork
2. Century egg porridge
3. Steamed pork ribs
4. Steamed chicken claw

Very good service. Overall the dishes are not bad, but the price is a little on the high side.
Lucky our queue wasn't too long. Had a great brunch and variety of dim sum to choose.

This is one of my tasty, authentic and value for money restaurant! My buddies and I couldn’t believe the reasonable pricing and the nostalgic taste we been missing all these years. The must try: Orh Lua, pig trotted jelly, fried caipoh Kuay Teow and caipoh egg. OMG. We going again next week! 👍🏻

Tried the Dim Sum and overall good experience. The pan fried Carrot Cake has good sear on it for favour and taste. The Salted Egg Lava Bun was so-so, didn't have that good oozing of the salted egg lava.

Do not go for the dim sum buffet. Web stated 3-5pm, 430pm the staff will chased all the customer away. A lot of item is not in the buffet. All staff very rude, attitude in services. Worst restaurant I ever been.
Old school dim sum house with waitresses pushing dim sum carts around. Taste is avg.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content:
We've been patronising Crystal Jade since they started and through the years they have expanded and grew more outlets.

Different outlet's chefs perform differently hence we have favourite outlets. Our first choice used to be at Holland Village. Another favourite haunt is the one at Ngee Ann City.

Recently, we've been ordering from their Toa Payoh outlet for home delivery. Although the experience is not as good as in-house dining, the convenience and quality of the takeout more than makes up for it.

My grandchildren love their beef so we usually order 2 portions. Another favourite dish we would order in twos is the four season beans. The lion head meatball stew is delicious but I prefer a more meaty bite. I find them a little mushy for my taste but perhaps the young children and older folks may like it that way. The tofu stew is also very delicious. I appreciate that they pack the sweet and sour fish sauce separately from the fried fish. Overall, we are happy with our delivered meals and will continue to order from this outlet.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content:
Love coming here to chill with the family because it’s spacious and quiet, away from the crowd especially on weekends.

First time trying the la mian with chilled poached chicken Szechuan style and it’s good! Everything blend well together, have it with steamed dumplings and you have a complete meal.

The kids meal comes with a generous portion and the prawn dumplings are filled with meat fillings and prawns. Sweet potato bun is beautiful to look at and sweet too, not my kids favourite but I like it 😂😂 Kids meal comes with a free drink too :)

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Great Northern Chinese cuisine! Crystal Jade is a well-known chain in Singapore and the Toa Payoh branch lives up to expectations. The service was fast and friendly, and the food was tasty and fresh.  A guarantee.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Didn't know expect to have authentic Sichuan food from crystal jade. Highly recommend the Chong Qing Pickled Mustard Grilled Fish and the Chong Qing La Mian. Shiok! The sweet potato pastry is not too sweet.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: I used to visit this place but haven’t been back in a while. Decided to have lunch here. The soup for Dan Dan mian was way too thick, and spicy too. Don’t mind the spiciness, but the soup was a too “jelak”. Order the fried duck, it was good. But portion is too small for the price I feel. The salted egg custard bao was the best dish we had. Hence the 3 stars.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Good and prompt service. They have a digital queue system so you can get a number first and they will ring you when ready. Very convenient and great innovation to handle during peak hours.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content:
Food is great.
Love the si-chuan cold noodle with chicken. Really delicious & my family enjoyed it.
Fried rice was average.
Oh yes.. and XLB was nice.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Food is higher priced than its competitors. But they make the yummiest xiao long bao. I wish they have more menu cos the food choices are quite limited.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content:
Not worth the $82 for 2 pax for the Xiao Long Bao buffet b'cos they took a long time to serve only 2 trays (6 pcs each tray) per order. What kind of buffet that set such ordering limit?

You have to keep chasing "what's happening to my XLB?". It looks like they prefer that you filled your stomach with their 2 complementary bowls of la mien and a side dish which you are not allow reject.

After long waiting in between orders, you begin to feel full and your marginal utility drop drastically and hence lost appetite for more XLB.

So be careful not to fall for this type of promotional gimmick which wasn't sincere at all.

Writing them off after this bad experience. Sigh !!!

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Good location for quick meal 小笼包。friendly staff and prompt service with average food & price around $20++ per pax.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content:
Took a few dishes. Like the fried rice in the second picture and the vegetable puff in the first picture, better.
On 11 Dec 21, took New chicken salad, vegetable dumplings and pork collar sour vegetable in sour and spicy soup. Took glutinous rice cube in rice wine as dessert. Took hot milk tea Hong-Kong style.  As shown in the last 4 pictures. The vegetable dumplings and hot milk tea Hong-Kong style were commendable.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content:
Could be better. My fav has always been dingtaifeng. Ahahaha..

Try again recently and their 葱油面 is sooo good! Didn’t even know this exist! Will come back again for more!!!

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Pleasant family restaurant in Toa Payoh central. Most dishes ordered are decent, except for the shen Chian pao(pan fried Shanghai pork bun) which has rather thick pastry and not enough meat. Service is prompt and courteous.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Ordered drunken chicken, fried rice,  sheng jian bao and they tasted quite bad, the standard in this branch is way below average of other branches. Not worth paying. I would take my money to other crystal jade outlets. Giving two star only coz egg white conpoy tasted ok.. You've been warned.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Average chinese cuisine in TPY. XLB's skin is a tad too thick but the meat filling is decent while the different flavours (normal, black truffle, chili crab and salted egg) are interesting. Generally fine though the dessert (red bean pastry) is a nice end to the meal with the crust light and crispy.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: most dishes we tried are pretty good. except the price. but then it's crystal jade so price is not expected to be friendly. The staffs however are. The cold chicken dish is surprisingly good. The prawn paste fried chicken didn't seem to blend well with the other dishes having too strong prawny smell. overall it's a good meal, but likely to visit again when strike 4D, or it's a company event.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Enjoyed a casual lunch here after running errands in the Toa Payoh neighbourhood. We almost always order the same favourites whenever we dine here: crispy bait Wuxi-style, dan dan noodles, xiao long bao & mala spiced dumplings. Yums, never fail to satisfy.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Came here to grab a bite and it turn out to be a feast. I enjoyed the sautéed Colourful vegetable assortment which is nice and crunchy. The crispy beancurd sheet wrapped with assorted mushroom is well prepared. The braised Dong Po Pork Belly with lotus bun is worth a try - it’s nice and tender and almost melts in your mouth. The sautéed Shanghai rice flour cake is average but the rice flour definitely is light on the bite which is rare to come by. This place is hidden from the main view so you need look out as you walk by.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Ordered through Foodpanda. Did not pack the ginger that goes with the Xiao long pau. Even tip a idelivery rider to request for extra ginger. Not even get a single slice of ginger!!

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Crystal jade jiangnan specialises in la mien and does it well. The menu also includes some cantonese cuisine and dim sum.  Some lovely dishes that I would go back for more would by the seafood crispy noodles and multi grain fried rice and the xiao long bao. The chunky seafood with its gravy was thoughtfully set aside to prevent the crispy noodles from turning soft too quickly. I like generous chunks of fish squid mushrooms prawns and a dash of leafy green that made this dish a seafood haven. It was well executed without being overly salty. That goes the same for the multi grain brown rice that was well cooked and presented in a stone bowl. Absolutely delicious and very healthy indeed! They have a spread of various types of xiaolong bao but I would recommend the normal flavour that allows you to experience the delicate yet flavorful pork infused with a delicious broth and sealed within the dumpling.  I wasn't too impressed with the lao sao bao which had very little filling making it rather dry;  and the ying yang steamed dumpling that had the skin too thick and the filling devoid of flavour. Service is alright though it would be ideal to make reservations if the group is large due to the small seating area.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: One of the many Crystal Jade outlets serving traditional Chinese cuisine from the different provinces of China. Food quality is decent and certainly good valued. Won't blow a hole in the wallet. Service is quite efficient even during peak hours. 3.5 stars

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: nice place, lots of menu choices

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content:
Since this is rather close to my office, I have been there about 2-3 times.

Service is pretty alright, the service staff is prompt in refilling our tea and would recommend us dishes each time (but they won’t let us know if we over ordered, so have to really gauge yourself).

Food wise is okay, portion is generous even when it’s $1 promotional dishes. The fried veggies were quite nice, xiao long pao tasted so-so.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content:
Good quality dishes at ok prices. Xiao long bao is priced wayyy too expensive than other similar restaurants though it's delicious.

Love their crispy scallion prata dish. Yes it's just roti prata but they made it so crispy it's irresistible. 炸酱面 is also quite different from other places I've eaten at, but good.

Don't order the drunken chicken. It uses too much Chinese wine.

Tea and wet towels are chargeable.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Glad to get a table for 4 with no dinner reservation. Lo hei is good, generous portion even we ordered small. Service is great, staffs are very patient and paid special attention to serve peanuts and sesame separately for our friend with allergy.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: This... is one of the worst crystal jade I’ve ever eaten at. I could go on and on about how bad the food is. The shanghai nian gao was totally off putting. It looks terrible and tastes worse. It’s bland, sweet and ugly all at the same time. Jelly fish was too soggy. The promotional item, hainanese xiao long bao tastes like dessert meat. It’s oh so sweet. The crispy fried beancurd skin was seeping in oil. Drunkard chicken is tough and salty. The har gao is too peppery and beneath the peppery mask is soggy smelly prawns. The worst thing? The damage for all these is $80++

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: This place is one of those which begs for help during covid but ignore u when business is back to normal. When me and my colleagues went there to eat, we spent about 100 plus with drinks included. While eating at chatting, as long as one person food is finished the waitress immediately clear the plate while others are still eating. It gives the rest of the people pressure to eat faster. Yes granted there was a queue outside but we have been there since covid period to support. But when business oicks up, they keep clearing your plates while others are eating. Hinting to u that u should leave soon. Problem is drinks are refillable for tea at it cost 3dollars per cup. Yet while we are still chatting and drinking they keep the cups too. This for me is too much. Come up to us and tell us that if we are able to go off for them to accommodate people inside to eat. I will not feel so bad. But as a restaurant, you should know people paid for everything including drinks and yet you keep everything to chase us off? Your call if you want to eat there.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content:
Had their afternoon tea set ($10.80++), comprising of a bowl of la mian, a dian xin and a glass of milk tea. La mian was good, dian xin were horrible except for the chilli-oil dumplings. Milk tea ok.

I miss the quality of their high-tea a-la-carte buffet during pre-covid days. It was certainly worth it.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content:
Used to be great. Now after the menu changed, food is cooked differently too. Usual nice food replaced with questionable combinations of food, options are too limited. Signature homemade barley was also removed. Overall, dropped from the expected 5 star experience from Crystal Jade to 3.

With high prices and a reputation to uphold, I expected way better.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: The standard has dropped drastically. The 葱油饼 is literally like prata with a tiny count of spring onions. Where is the supposedly copious amount of 葱？Next, the fried rice was bland, not much of wok hei. Last feedback was that the 流沙包 was steaming hot outside but cold on the inside. Granted that they got it changed eventually but the deed was already done. I love Crystal Jade but this time was very disappointed. Hope they improve.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: It was unpleasent . Staff don’t know about their promotion and insist they are right . I think worst exprience so far will not go back again. Management called to explain but i had already dine in without any promotion . I hope when customer see this , be wary of the term and condition .

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Service was average, did not clear the empty plates while they serve new dishes and when crew sees glass empty they did not take initiative to ask and refill. Need to prompt them, then they will clear for us and refill. The Yu-Sheng presentation was one of the worse. Totally no green as u see from the photo. Taste was okay though. Dim sum did not match the price, nothing unique about it.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content:
I order la mian beef with spicy soup.
But I think this is pork belly.
No more photo in the menu .

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Went for Easter brunch there excellent Cantonese cuisine and pretty reasonable pricing with great ambience and the service is fast and good 👍👍👍

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Yo if the dude asks you if you want this pickle side dish thing, WARNING: its $3.80. Food is decent, nothing too special.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Can't go wrong having your fix of Chinese cuisine at Crystal Jafe

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Wasn’t crowded when our family was dining in. Probably 5-6 tables occupied but kitchen couldn’t keep up with orders. Overheard countless conversations of wrong orders amongst servers. Service was also quite slow despite the small crowd size.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Good overall taste good, but the attitude not very nice  and service of the staff is slow

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Visited on 25th June where dining is only allowed 2 per table. We are a family of 3 so we had to sit seperated. I giving 5 stars to their service! I wanted to ordered some food for sharing but we couldn't cross table for sure. And I definitely couldn't finished all the food on my own so the staff initiate to divide the food into 2 serving for us when overheard our conversation. Really appreciated their service especially during this period of time!

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Chilli beef noodle was so-so. Same for the multi coloured XLBs.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Tasty food, pricey but expected. Service was mediocre and the atmosphere was cosy. Went on a Sunday afternoon and it wasnt crowded. Decent waiting time of about 5-10mins. Well staffed.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Better than Ding Tai Fung 🥳

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Outlet manager Amanda Chin is very friendly n polite. Was surprised she can recognise me and my preference seating area on my second visit. Other serving staff n food taste are also great..kudos to great customer experience !😀

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content:
Been a loyal customer to this restaurant for a very long time but today’s incident really question whether I would patronised the place ever again.

Was told before ordering that there was a 15% discount promotion if we sign up as member so we happily order more than usual. After ordering we were told to we can only sign up via their apps. Despite trying many many times, the app cannot register our membership. The staff told us the discount cannot be given unless we registered as member through their apps. So after so much trouble and repeated attempts, it was still unsuccessful as the apps OTP doesn’t work.  If u go to apps store page,  u can see a lot of bad comments on their apps.

In the end, we were forced to pay full price without the promised discount. Not sure it was a scam but I definitely feel cheated. It is their apps that doesn’t work, they didn’t honour their offer and we were forced to pay full price for more dishes that we normally order in anticipation of their offer. Maybe I will consider coming back when the moon turn green one day. Utterly a very disappointing experience. Thumbs down 👎👎👎

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Lovely food. The pan-fried pork buns and fried thick noodles with cabbage and mushrooms are my favourites. Place is clean, comfortable and the service is very good too. It's also less crowded because it's not in a shopping mall. Recommended.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Good food. But located in a corner that is not easy to find.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Like dishes, staff friendly and attentive!

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Been awhile since I last visited a crystal jade LMXLB. Food wise, pretty much the same standard except for the radish pastry which was a tinge more orange and the filling was not as wet" and flavorful from what I cld recall. Service was friendly, prompt and accomodating.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Love the spicy and nutty dan dan noodles since the restaurant's days at Takashimaya.

restaurant name: Crystal Jade La Mian Xiao Long Bao
content: Crystal Jade Dim Sum turned out better and cheaper than expected. 🤓🤓 #Burpple

Stumbled upon this non air-con Teochew restaurant. I like Teochew cuisine so why not. Ordered 3 simple dishes for lunch and they turned out good.
The standard of its Teochew braised duck, 潮州卤水鸭, is good enough to convince me to return again to try the other traditional Teochew dishes this restaurant has to offer.
It is reasonably priced too.
Only thing is.... No air-con 😅

Walked past this restaurant few weeks ago and saw many people enjoying their steam boat with “imperial design” steamboats. Finally booked the restaurant for the family dinner. We enjoyed the steamboat… super fresh fish and soup was flavorful and not salty.

I love the braised duck… meat was super soft and simply delicious.

Making a reservation was a bit of a mess… they used WhatsApp but when we arrived, they didn’t capture the reservation. So call the restaurant to be sure. Try to get a seat at the extension area of the restaurant where it is much cooler.

Service was fine. We over ordered until need to dabao. Lol. Should have opted for small size instead of medium steamboat, esp there are other dishes in the order 😅. The 20% discount for members only on the fish steamboat. I will revisit for the steamboat, chef popiah( surprisingly good and only on certain days) and yam paste.

If only there's minus star* The rice dumplings are simply terrible. They have no respect for food at all and their profession.
Bought 5 of those dumplings home, was told that it can be eaten straight or just simply heat it up by the staff. Went home that evening, opened one, the meat was disappointing, very tough and dry, I think it was less than 1 quarter of the whole dumpling..
the rice is not cook thoroughly and tasteless... sad evening...

How worst it get?
Well, the next morning, we open the rest of the 4 dumpling, it was all the same... no, worst, 1 even spoilt just 1 overnight, that kind of set me thinking, how long have those  $#!+ been sitting there... sad morning..
It cost $4/pc, totally not worth.

Called in to complaint, asked for management, the staff simply say: "I don't know, I don't know" part of their training? 🤔

Conclusion:
Terrible food, terrible people, terrible business...

$188 set dinner. The dishes that stood out for me is the imperial pot with fish maw. Full of flavour and ingredients, and the yam paste dessert with white nuts was good too. The duck was ok. They ran out of Garoupa, offered prawns instead. The crab seemed very small but tastes good. Wet wipes are chargeable. The day that we were there, there was only 1 staff serving. We had to help ourselves to the various sauces and serving spoons. The air-condition was not turned on until requested. Ala carte may be better? The dining experience seemed abit stressed being under staffed and humid.

Got to try this restaurant for the very first time about 9 years ago when they were still located at Rivervally. Their fish porridge and braised duck are quite popular amongst the regulars.

Duck : ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ (can be softer)
Porridge : ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
Salted Egg Toufu : Better to remove from menu
Pumpkin Yam Paste (Or Ni) : ⭐️⭐️⭐️ (blend well before eating)

Came on the recommendation of friends. The place is actually made up of a Teochew restaurant, a dim sum stall, and a drink stall. Private rooms and airconditioned sections are available. The charcoal fish-head steamboat came out with a battered pot and sooted chimney, signs of frequent usage (popular dish). The soup was creamy and salty which suits my palate (unlike other brands that tend to be slightly sweet), and the base used in the soup was fried fish. I could taste yam, prominent salted plum, and butter. Belachan chilli was not spicy despite the mean look. The other unusual stuff that came with it was the shredded fried egg. The raw fish slices provided were fresh. We also tried charsiew bao and liu sha bao and were not impressed.

Friends suggested going to this place at Toa Payoh Lorong 8 teochew steamboat.  The soup is thick and flavourful. Fish is very fresh. Enjoyed the food there.  Place have a traditional look. Service-wise, there were good ones, and not so "attentive" ones.
Nice teochew resturant, 24hrs dim sum available. Fish steamboat smells really good, Will definitely come back to try again.
Good dim sum at late hours. Authentic teochew settings and menu. Loved their fish porridge.

Had the imperial streamboat, the small portion was very generous. Comes with raw slices fish on the side, with extra veg, mushrooms and fried eggs to add on the streamboat looks very rustic and authentic.

The staff was very attentive ans polite.

Overall this was a very good experience.

The waitress who looks like a senior staff doesn’t even know peppercorn vs black pepper. I am well versed in both English and Chinese so the menu clearly is understood by me. Plus I love to enjoy food.  But not here. Sure, she is rude but I waited to see if the food is any good.   That glutinous rice rolls are horribly salty, the rice is not even cooked at a good temperature and everything is just mashed up and salty.  Doesn’t even have the fresh taste.  The so called chicken dish is so normal. The rice is really not cooked well(a restaurant with messed up rice….), they mess up the order, comes over to do a so called I am sorry the kitchen made a mistake.  So the kitchen can’t even understand orders?  Anyway, is there a minus star?  Google team, we really need some attention here, so many people with bad taste buds or fake reviews are being paid for it?  I am strongly against bad food.  Bad service. For the price doesn’t even do any justice.

Environment is okay, next to market.
Dim sum not freshly made, taste is average.

Porridge taste good, prices are reasonable.

No services charge.
Will come again for the porridge.

ig: @_bluebulb

First time trying the fish steamboat and it was delicious. Had the whole grouper where the meat is fillet to cook separately. The head and bones were deep fried and cooked in the broth with lots of vegetables, tofu and yam. Pair with the sambal belacan adds flavour to the veg and tofu.
The steamboat is really nice. The soup is a bit salty. Portions are reasonable. We ordered a few more dishes.

Having walked pass the shop for so long, finally a visit. Very busy this particular evening. Extensive menu with not so many Teochew dishes. Food was ordinary tasting by me. Duck's braising liquid could do with stronger flavors. Kway teow lacked wok hei. Orr jiang was overly starchy for my liking. Sugar coated yam was fantastic! Just as I remembered when granny had made these many moons ago. Siew Mai filled with prawns instead of pork or fish paste was a wonderful delight, like ones you will find in a proper cantonese restaurant. Being very reasonably priced dining here makes it up. So it's a mix bag of hits and misses in here. Shall look forward to try the rest of their menu offerings.

Yes, very yummy fish steamboat, cold crabs and Teochew braised duck with beancurd.
We will there on 24 Feb to celebrate my birthday.

First time trying with my family of 3. Previously they don't have dim sum but they do now.

We had:

1. Steam carrot cake
2. Steam beancurd roll
3. Steam Xiaolong Bao
4. Steam Prawn Chives Dumpling
5. Seafood Roll

Dim sum no GST but ala carte has.

Total damage is about $35.

I have been having my teochew fix here for awhile now. Love the fish steamboat! The soup is milky and rich and full of ingredients. Theres fried fish in it and also a plate of raw fish slices, tons of veg and fried egg in it. Love the braised duck and my dad loves the pork jelly. Theres another branch at bukit batok which I frequent as well but tt outlet doesnt have steamboat option. Overall great place and portion is very generous too! 😍

Steamboat is definitely good, broth is flavourful and tasty but can get too salty towards the end..Oyster omelette is also strongly recommended but the rest of dishes such as dim sum, sweet & sour pork, fried tofu, the mixed platter wouldn't be missed. Braised items are also below average.

In conclusion, there are only 2 star items on the items.

Service is slow and expect nothing more. Dishes are also not served in sequence.

If you are not going for steamboat, then don't bother.
First meal after the SHN. It was delicious. Perfect steam fish. Yum yum
Soup is nice and thick, sliced fish is fresh too! Went there twice in 1 week.

Went for a belated father’s day lunch at the restaurant today and met a dishonest cashier. There was supposed to be a 10% membership discount. My sis asked if the discount has been applied and the cashier said Yes. Thankfully, my sister was alert enough and asked to see the original receipt (before discount). The cashier looked uncomfortable and presented the correct receipt.

Not sure how many times unknowing customers have been scammed.

Food is decent but please check your receipt before paying.

Dim Sum is affordable and tasty too! Worth it!. Their Chai Por Hor Fun (dried radish hor fun) has much wok hei and flavour.

The fish soup been hoon is done with long hours of brewing fish bones. They don't skimp on raw ingredients.
Nice foods especially the pig trotter jelly and the braised duck.

The fried fish head soup steamboat is excellent. The sliced fish is very fish and smooth. Good broth that the staff keep topping up. The egg was a bit salty, the spring was ok, not bad. The pu er tea taste a bit different. Will be back to try the 24hra dim sum dishes too

Decent food at an appropriate price, was surprised to find out that they are opened 24 hours. Tried their fish head hot pot, braised duck (my fave from them) and others, though to be fair, the dishes were a little too salty for my taste.

The set menu has all the signature dish, all are good except the Chili Crab which was spicy with chili but not the crab source as what you expect for SG Chili Crab. Need to book during weekend dinner peak hour

Terrible arrival to hear that they didn't recurs your dinner bookings for 7. And there was a long line of angry customers waiting to walk in. There is only one mgr looking lady. But she's not manning the reservation. She's was also taking orders from customers seated already. Asked the other junior staff and they just ignore and indicated it was not their responsibility.

The owner should relook at how they allocate staff appropriately.

After dinner, I have to queue to pay and that takes another 20min in the queue.

I will never come back. Period.

The fish head steamboat is a must try, ideal for 4 pax or more. Comes with Groupa or promfet (scan QR picture to check food and dim sum.menus), fish bones are deep fried before stewing in the pot, heated by charcoal. Side plate of nai nai veggies, enoki mushrooms and fried egg. Service staff attentive, keeps on topping up soup base.

You can order dim sum or from a la carte or set meal.

Came for their dim sum today and was really authentic and good. Service was quite fast despite an almost full house. Their steamed pork ribs is a must try. Ample parking at the HDB carpark. A good choice to spend your weekend morning.

Enjoyed the Jing Tai Lan steamboat, which came with large, fresh slices of red grouper and lots of vegetables. The only issue was that the the broth could have had a deeper, more natural flavour. The Teochew oyster omelette was great with large oysters and a good number of them. The nai bai was fine.

Went to this Tim Sum place this morning.The place did not seem to be that crowded. So we sat down and tried to get the waitress'  attention to make an order .The waitress indicated for  me to wait. But for what? She walked  up and down the restaurant as though she was  very busy. Got fed up with  the service and walked  out..i wonder whats wrong with this place. Anyway sorry to the boss for having such workers.. your loss for not training them about customer service..

Came here few times ,use like the fish soup here and dim sum. Fish head steamboat. Decided to write feedback here ..think is my last time here ..  the service really BAD .. no one asking you or bother you want to dine in ? We stand big there quite sometime and keep asking for a table .. the restaurant seem not full occupied.. And then waited to place order .. they serve wrong food , and they even say sorry and the staff look like very busy to answer you .. the fish soup not as nice as last few times we came .Service too bad , price also increased a lot  won’t think coming back again. !

Fish head steamboat here is the best i’ve had so far. Every dish is savoury and awesome. Cold crab was just normal not fantastic. left out of the pictures is this cai po kwai teow that , i kid you not, the best i’ve had in my life so far. really awesome!! Definitely order the kwai teow. No regrets. Fish head steamboat is a cut above all the other steamboats i’ve ever had. $65 for a small one. It was enough to go around for my mum, wifey and me. Generous Fresh tasty fish slices and they constantly refill the super savoury soup! i signed up for the member and got a instant 20% disc on the steamboat. We also had yam paste for dessert (pumpkin and ginkgo options available) Service was excellent, generous refill of soups, tea. was there on a weekday evening and was not crowded. I would definitely visit again and strongly recommend to anyone looking for a hearty, satisfying chinese cuisine meal . :)
Food is pretty good while service can improve
Ordered dry burning fish head and the dish was not even warm. Asked the staff to make it hot and ended up with a warm dish instead. Give up!

Love that it's open round the clock! Soup is good and really affordable, fish slices are fresh too. Ordered fish head steamboat, one sweet sour pork (in ice), a couple dim sum and red bean pancake for 6, less than 15 per pax

bought 3 rice dumplings, both fillings only a bit, full of uncooked rice. staff is rude, and don't know how to tie different colour string for different dumplings.

at first i thought it's only 1 piece maybe they put a bit of meat only, turns out all 3 pieces inside meat like this photo.

see photo yourself, $3.80 each, a few meagre pieces of dry hard meat. taste bad also, don't think will even try the restaurant. please warn others.

honestly, i have never been so angry, and tasted something so bad. i have had better one that only cost $2.50 each with more meat inside.

pokgai pui cao nua

Had a very bad experience last week. I wish I could give 0 stars.
Went to buy takeaway for 3 portions of fried rice but was treated with absolute disrespect by the female Chinese cashier. Rude and disrespectful, slammed the receipt on the table and rudely shouted at me to take it while I was preparing to pay.
Will not patronise this shop ever.

Great Service Chinese Teochew 'Authentic Restaurant Very classic.
Food was great Especially the Fresh Fish Steamboat
Deep fried Prawn Rolls and Braised Duck was Tender and flavourful.
Cold Crab was great
Overall Very impressive
Hidden behind Lor 8 Toa Payoh Market

Really like the batang fish porridge as the soup is thick and tasty, alot of fish. $12 for 2 person and should be enough for 3 person. Tim sum is handmade, 20% discount after 10pm. No gst or service charge and is open 24hrs.

On the contrary to most reviewers, attendants were attentive BUT VERY CONFUSED.. That was mostly about the orders and availability of dishes, the rest of the dinner was well enjoyed..
Food was delicious and the fish steamboat we came for was delectable (I would hope so, given the price). Not to forget, they are opened 24 hours, I can come at any hour when I miss the soup..
The fish porridge is superb! Very flavorful! Gonna try for new goers! Their seafood porridge too! Ordered 2 porridge and good for 3 pax sharing! Will go back again!
The fishhead steamboat is famous and must try, rest maybe hits n misses, according to my accompanying diners

Had their $13.80nett dim sum buffet but alot of items were already unavailable or left one or two in stock upon arrival, what we ordered here are mostly what they left with on a Sunday mid afternoon.

Pan fried turnip cake, fried prawn dumplings, siew mai, ju chong fun are the better tasting items off whatever they are left.

My first visit here, not sure when they have most items but this place runs 24hrs, dim sum are all handmade, probably explains the lack of variety.

Very tasty steamboat, piping hot and rich. Staff keep filling soup. Fish is gd quality.

Jan 21 - 2nd visit. teochew fish porridge is excellent. $6 1 pot. See picture below. die die must try

April 4 - 3rd visit. Fish porridge standard maintained. The 韮菜饺 skin very thin, prawn very fresh
Normal fish steamboat. Not much flavoured soup, taste more of msg. Some of serving staff are very rude.

24 hours teochew cuisine and cantonese handmade timsum. Nice ambience, friendly staff and good food at reasonable price. Located next to lor 8 Toa Payoh Market n Food centre.
10pm to 10am 20% discount.

Have been here several times for the steamboat (fried fish and slice fresh fish). The thick soup base is excellent, all of my guests love it. It's restaurant price but all dishes are served in big portion and services are always good.
